Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: The most infamous tornado of the outbreak occurred on March 14 when an isolated EF2 tornado caused widespread damage across Downtown Atlanta, Georgia, including to the CNN Center and to the Georgia Dome, which was hosting the 2008 SEC men's basketball tournament.
Other buildings that were damaged include the Georgia World Congress Center, and the Omni Hotel, which was evacuated after many windows were blown out.
The Westin Peachtree Plaza Hotel suffered major window damage. The image of the building with all its windows blown out became famous and for a time was a symbol of the tornado.
Centennial Olympic Park, SunTrust Plaza (now Truist Plaza) and historic Oakland Cemetery were also damaged.

Total_Summary_Deaths.Total_Deaths_Annotation: One man was killed near Downtown Atlanta and 30 others were injured. Two other deaths took place on March 15, in the northern Atlanta suburbs, from a second, larger round of severe weather and tornadoes.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: CNN Center was severely damaged, including shattered windows. All of CNN's TV networks remained on the air, but there was damage to the glass roof of the CNN Center atrium flooding part of the food court. Additionally, blown-out windows in the ground floor CNN.com newsroom and the fourth floor videotape library caused minor damage.

The Georgia World Congress Center sustained serious damage and also sustained flooding while hosting a JROTC event and the Hinman Dental Meeting; Fox Sports Net captured footage of a staircase in the new section that looked like a fountain with water cascading down it.
The Omni Hotel, especially the skywalk between the two hotel towers over Andrew Young International Boulevard, lost 476 windows, making it necessary to close the south tower to guests.
The facades of the Georgia Dome and a Philips Arena parking garage were damaged while hosting basketball games.

These buildings had windows blown out (with 300 at Equitable Building alone). Additionally, the windows of the Westin continued to fall for days after the tornado, forcing police to keep several city blocks and MARTA's Peachtree Center station closed to pedestrians. (Note: SunTrust Plaza is noted here for building damage as well as displacement in a separate record.)
At the nearby Philips Arena, damage occurred to the exterior during the game between the Hawks and the Los Angeles Clippers, even though little disruption was noticed by attendees.
Over 20 homes were completely destroyed.
The historic Rialto Theatre at GSU sustained roof damage, which caused water damage inside.
Grady Hospital reported damage to windows and a power outage.
The King Memorial MARTA station was damaged and was being bypassed by trains, with buses rerouted to the next station on each side.
A brick loft building in the Cabbagetown area lost part of its roof and part of its top (fifth) floor.
Another building at The Stacks on Boulevard was damaged; search and rescue personnel were unable to enter, though everyone was accounted for by management within a few hours.
More than 60 people had to be relocated out of their offices at SunTrust Plaza.

Total_Summary_Injuries.Total_Injuries_Annotation: Twenty-seven people were treated for injuries.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: Many of the injured were taken to Grady Hospital, with some treated in the emergency room for cuts due to glass. In total, twenty-seven people were treated for injuries.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage_Annotation: At the time, it was the most expensive tornado in Atlanta history, in raw U.S. dollars, after the 1999 Oklahoma City tornado, costing a half-billion dollars.

Time_Annotation: President Bush declared a major disaster on March 20.[75]
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Atlanta’s state of emergency was declared by Mayor Shirley Franklin and Governor Sonny Perdue, and President Bush’s declaration of a major disaster (all in the context of U.S. response) indicates the event affected the United States.[73][74][75]
Main_Event_Annotation: The article states, 'When the tornado hit, a SEC tournament game between Mississippi State and Alabama was in progress at the Georgia Dome' and later notes it as the most expensive tornado in Atlanta history.[67][76]
Hazards_Annotation: Multiple sentences describe severe wind damage – trees being blown down, panels ripped from building exteriors, shattered windows, and roofs damaged – which supports 'Wind' as the hazard associated with the tornado.[64][67]

Time_Annotation: On October 16, 2014, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Climate Prediction Center issued its U.S. Winter Outlook, and on November 30, 2014, Environment Canada's monthly prediction system produced a forecast for the months of December, January, and February.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The outlook covers various parts of the United States (south‐central, southeastern, western regions, Alaska, Hawaii, New England) and forecast details for Canada (including areas such as British Columbia, Yukon, Northwest Territories, etc.).
Main_Event_Annotation: The forecast primarily addresses temperature anomalies – with below‐average temperatures in some regions and above‐average in others – which aligns with an Extreme Temperature event category.
Hazards_Annotation: The outlook predicts below-average temperatures (indicative of a Cold Spell) in parts of the United States and Canada, while other regions are forecast to experience above-average temperatures (suggesting potential Heatwave conditions).

Time_Annotation: In early November 2014, Typhoon Nuri peaked in intensity as a Category 5-equivalent typhoon on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale. The storm became extratropical on November 8, and it was absorbed by a new center of circulation.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The storm weakened as it moved westward, and it produced a 'ripple' in the jet stream which allowed for a strong cold front to dive southward out of Canada into the United States, producing a cold wave.
Main_Event_Annotation: The storm became extratropical on November 8, and it was absorbed by a new center of circulation. The new, more powerful cyclone entered the Bering Sea, and intensified to become the most powerful storm to ever impact the region.
Hazards_Annotation: In association with the storm, there were winds exceeding hurricane-force with a wind gust of 97 miles per hour (156 km/h) recorded at Shemya, Alaska.

Time_Annotation: The text notes that 'the low began to coalesce into a winter storm in the first two days of 2015' and later mentions 'On January 1, 2015, Los Angeles experienced a record low' as well as 'the storm system then gradually moved out into Canada by January 4' with record cold persisting through January 8.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The article states an arctic cold front swept into the Northwestern United States and later that 'the storm system then gradually moved out into Canada by January 4', indicating both countries were affected.
Main_Event_Annotation: The article explains that 'while bringing a wide swath of wintry weather ... the winter storm also brought along with it a cold wave, in which some places broke record low temperatures,' indicating an extreme temperature event.
Hazards_Annotation: The report of record low temperatures in Los Angeles, Pasadena, Estcourt Station (Maine), Montpelier (Vermont), and Jackson (Kentucky) supports the identification of a 'Cold Spell' hazard.

Time_Annotation: The article states 'On January 23, a low-pressure area developed off the Pacific Northwest' and later notes 'Early on January 30, the nor'easter left the East Coast,' which define the start and end of the event.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The text mentions that the system moved 'quickly moving over the Canadian Prairies by January 24' (indicating Canada) and affected regions such as the Pacific Northwest, Upper Midwest, Kentucky-Tennessee border, Bluefield, West Virginia, and the East Coast (all within the United States).
Main_Event_Annotation: The description includes a path 'typical of an Alberta clipper' and later refers to the system as a 'nor'easter,' both of which are characteristics of an extratropical storm/cyclone.
Hazards_Annotation: The article notes that 'moisture from the Gulf of Mexico wrapped around the system, resulting in widespread rainfall and snow over the Midwest' and 'snowfall remained concentrated along a cold front,' which together indicate hazards of both flooding (from heavy rain) and blizzard conditions (from heavy snowfall) as expected for an extratropical storm.

Event_Names: 2015 Northeastern United States Extreme Temperature Event
Time_Annotation: The article mentions that 'Nine states in the Northeast United States had one of their coldest January–March periods on record' and specifically notes that Boston experienced 43 consecutive days below 40°F from January 20 through March 3, 2015.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The text refers to the event occurring across nine states in the Northeast, including places like Boston, Massachusetts; Providence, Rhode Island; Eastport, Maine; and others, all of which are located within the United States.
Main_Event_Annotation: The event is characterized as one of the coldest periods on record with record low temperatures, which aligns with an extreme temperature event as seen in the description of prolonged subfreezing conditions.
Hazards_Annotation: The report of record-breaking low temperatures and an extended period (43 days) of temperatures below 40°F indicates a cold spell hazard, which is the associated hazard for an Extreme Temperature event.

Event_Names: 2015 Western United States Extreme Temperature Event
Time_Annotation: The article states, 'temperatures in the Western United States averaged above normal for December' and later that 'California, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming all experienced a top-10 warm January in 2015.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Locations and states are mentioned throughout the text, including 'southern Idaho' (Pocatello), 'Salt Lake City, Utah', 'Ontario, Oregon', 'Fresno, California', 'Mount Shasta', and the explicit listing of 'California, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming' as well as 'Winslow, Arizona' and 'Tucson, Arizona'.
Main_Event_Annotation: The narrative describes record-setting warm conditions with phrases such as 'averaged above normal for December', 'warmest December on record', and 'experienced its warmest winter on the 120-year record', clearly indicating an extreme temperature event.
Hazards_Annotation: The evidence of unusually high temperatures, including record warm December readings (e.g., Fresno, California’s warmest December) and the warmest winter overall, aligns with the hazard of a heatwave as per the Extreme Temperature event category.

Time_Annotation: The article mentions that Toronto recorded its coldest month in February, Montreal experienced its coldest February with an extended cold spell, Guelph broke a record on February 13, ice cover in the Great Lakes was recorded by the end of February, and a record snowfall occurred by the end of April 2015.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Locations are cited in the text: 'Toronto, Ontario recorded its coldest month...', 'In Quebec, Montreal experienced its coldest February...', 'On February 13, Guelph, Ontario matched a 116-year-old record...', 'By the end of April 2015, a record 550 centimetres of snow fell on parts of the Prince Edward Island...', and 'by the end of February, the maximum extent of ice cover in the Great Lakes...'.
Main_Event_Annotation: The text highlights record low temperatures in Toronto, Montreal, and Guelph, as well as an extended cold spell in Montreal, indicating an Extreme Temperature event.
Hazards_Annotation: Based on the record low temperatures, the coldest month and February records, and the description of an extended cold spell in Montreal, the hazard is identified as a Cold Spell, which is the hazard associated with Extreme Temperature events.

Main_Event_Annotation: Key details such as '375 millimetres (14.8 in) fell for the 24 hours ending 22 March, flooding the rebuilt Great Ocean Road' and the mention that 'by May much of the Darling Downs was flooded' support the classification of the event under the Flood category.
Hazards_Annotation: The article highlights torrential rainfall and subsequent flooding – with descriptions of intense rain events in March and extended periods of heavy rain in April and May – which aligns with the hazard 'Flood' from the association table.
